Posts.Title: Do you ever feel guilty?? RobynK konakat

Posts.Content: Apr 2, 2010 12:03PM CathleenP wrote: Jenny, Stage IV is a cruel diagnosis. I'm still trying to understand it after 4.5 yrs as a Stage II. I too have mets to the bone and spine, and have some involvement--the painful kind--with the kidneys. But, as our friends on this chain have said, it's not over. You can live for a long time as a Stage IV. And, you can have a high quality of life. I recommend antidepresants and something for sleep like Ambien. I can get through most every bad news day without falling to my knees. You also don't seem to have a supportive care group. Fire them and move on to another team. I have learned that the breast cancer patient is in charge of her life--you make the decisions, you are the CEO of your situation. I don't know where you live, but with your background, you should be able to call on the big guns in bc oncology and get some excellent referrals. Taking charge may be difficult at first with all the emotional stuff swirling in your brain, but start with the antidepressants, get some sleep, and then make some phone calls. You will start feeling better almost immediately because you've given yourself some power. We're all here to support you. Take care, Cathleen

Posts.Content: CathleenP wrote: Hi, I get lost sometimes about the proper location for posts, but since I'm IV as well as a Femara gal, I use both.. Does anyone else get bruised easily (sometimes for no explicable reason, unless I'm punching myself at night)? Also, when I bruise those marks stick around for weeks. I look like a druggie (which I guess we all are!). Do you think these bruises are signs of something else?  Thanks, Cathleen Cathleen Dx 5/5/2009, ILC, 2cm, Stage IV, 6/11 nodes, ER-/PR-, HER2- Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Bruising CathleenP Kate2z80

Posts.Content: May 18, 2009 02:21PM CathleenP wrote: No one's going to judge you. The best thing you can do for all of us is to live another day, and another one, and....I personally love the SGK organization. I love the day of the Race for the Cure--everyone in DC is in a good mood; the Metro is full of pink and white T-shirts, and a lot of buzz. The city blossoms on that day with hope and support. It's one of my very favorite days. If you have ever wondered what it feels like to go for a walk with 80,000 people who are all in your corner, come to DC on June 6.

Posts.Content: May 23, 2009 02:21PM CathleenP wrote: I was just diagnosed with bone mets, after having had my ovaries out due to ovary mets--all going back to ILC four years ago. I just started Zometa on Thurs. The scheul will be once every 4 weeks. From all of your reports, I now understand why the nurse was so insisstent on making a distinction between once a month and once every 4 weeks. I don't have any side effects yet except for weariness, and that is a general side effect of bc, isn't it? Also my onc is currently looking at signing me up for one of two available clinical trials:  (1) faslodex + lapatriab (sp?? can't read his handwriting); or (2) femara & avastin. Just read the most horrible side effects of avastin alone. Perforated GI tract?  Anybody with advice? Help. Thank you! Cathleen

Posts.Content: Apr 1, 2010 09:35AM CathleenP wrote: I am so sorry to hear about the lack of support for you in your immediate environment. Facing cancer is a full-time job. I agree that calling the ACS would be a very good first new step, if you haven't already. Also, your oncologist's office and nurse might have some additional resources to offer you. Sometimes all you have to do is "ask for help." I am thinking of you and wishing our society wasn't so health care-stupid. Who is their right minds votes against hope for cancer patients? If you can get out, take a long walk today and breathe deeply. It helps me. Hugs, Cathleen

Posts.Content: CathleenP wrote: Hi Everyone, I will be seeing my onc's research director about clinical trials to deal with my newly dxed bone mets. All I know about my status is the two spots on my hips which showed up on the PETscan. Will they automatically do a bone marrow test for level of cancer? Do I need to request this? For those with bone mets, what is the usual course of treatment, and how did you do? My onc said more than likely I will not have chemo (I had a difficult regimen when dxed 4 years ago as a Stage II).  Thanks for any advice and comments.  Hugs to everyone, Cathleen Cathleen Dx 5/5/2009, ILC, 2cm, Stage IV, 6/11 nodes, ER-/PR-, HER2- Log in to post a reply

Posts.Content: May 25, 2009 02:29PM CathleenP wrote: Hi Luann, Thank you for the note. It's so easy to overreact to a list of nasty side effects. But, you're right about how they come up with the list. I was in a trial the first time around for Taxol/Gemzar; lo and behold, I developed appendicitis. Now it's on the list of possible side effects. Weird. Yes, even though I am Her-; I may be eligible for the F/L trial. I hope so. I never did well on AIs, that's the other trial, so Femara and Avastin doesn't sound as easy to me. Hope you are enjoying your long weekend! Cathleen
